questions.text: All of the following dural venous sinuses are enclosed in falx cerebri, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• The cerebral dura (Latin hard mother) mater made up of two layers.
    • An outer endosteal layer
    • An inner meningeal layer
  • It enclosing the cranial venous sinuses between the two.
  • The meningeal layer forms four folds which divide the cranial cavity into intercommunicating compartments for different parts of the brain.
  • Folds of dura matter: with sinuses enclosed in it
    • Falx cerebri
      • Superior saggital sinus
      • Inferior saggital sinus
      • Straight sinus
    • Falx cerebelli
      • Occipital sinus
    • Tentorium cerebelli
      • Transverse Sinus
      • Superior petrosal sinus
    • Diaphragma sellae
      • Anterior intercavernous sinus
      • Posterior intercavernous sinus

Key takeaways : The cerebral dura mater has an outer endosteal layer and an inner meningeal layer that form four folds (falx cerebri, falx cerebelli, tentorium cerebelli, and diaphragma sellae), compartmentalizing the cranial cavity and enclosing venous sinuses.

choices.text: Symptoms of cerebral compression are early
Paralysis first appears in the face and then spreads to lower part of body
There is no blood in CSF seen

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about extradural haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
• Extradural and subdural haemorrhages both are common.
  • An extradural haemorrhage can be distinguished from a subdural haemorrhage because of the following differences.
  • The extradural haemorrhage is arterial due to injury to middle meningeal artery, whereas subdural haemorrhage is venous in nature.
  • Symptoms of cerebral compression are late in extradural haemorrhage.
  • In an extradural haemorrhage, paralysis first appears in the face and then spreads to the lower parts of the body.
  • In a subdural haemorrhage, the progress of paralysis is haphazard.
  • In an extradural haemorrhage, there is no blood in the CSF, while it is a common feature of subdural haemorrhage.

Key takeaways : Extradural hemorrhage is an arterial bleed with late symptoms and facial paralysis progression, while subdural hemorrhage is venous with haphazard paralysis and blood present in the CSF.

questions.text: Which of the following haemorrhage is venous in nature?
questions.solution:
Type of haemorrhage Vessels/vessels most commonly involved

  • Extradural haemorrhage:
    • Rupture of anterior division of middle meningeal artery.
  • Subdural haemorrhage:
    • Tearing of superior cerebral (bridging) veins.
  • Subarachnoid haemorrhage:
    • Leakage or rupture of congenital berry aneurysms on the arterial circle of Willis.
  • Intracerebral (cerebral) haemorrhage
    • Rupture of thin-walled lenticulostriate artery (Charcot's artery of cerebral haemorrhage), a branch of the middle cerebral artery

Key takeaways : Extradural hemorrhage is an arterial bleed with late symptoms and facial paralysis progression, while subdural hemorrhage is venous with haphazard paralysis and blood present in the CSF.

questions.text: Spinal dura ends at the level of:
questions.solution:
• The spinal dura extends from foramen magnum to the lower border of second sacral vertebra (S2).
    • The space between spinal dura and vertebral canal is termed epidural space. This space contains loose areolar tissue, semiliquid fat and internal vertebral venous plexus.
    • The space between dura and arachnoid mater termed subdural space. It contains capillary layer of fluid.
  • Arachnoid mater is a thin delicate transparent avascular membrane which invests the spinal cord loosely.
    • Above it is continuous with the arachnoid mater of the brain and below it extends up to the lower border of the second sacral vertebra (S2).
  • Pia mater is a thin highly vascular membrane that closely invests the spinal cord.
    • It continues below the spinal cord as a thin thread-like prolongation, the filum terminale.
    • It ends at the level of 1st coccygeal vertebra.

Key takeaways : Spinal Cord Levels:

  • Adults: L1-L2
  • Children: L2-L3

choices.text: Disc between L1 and L2 vertebra
Disc between L2 and L3 vertebra
Disc between L3 and L4 vertebra
Disc between L4 and L5 vertebra

questions.text: Which of the following is most preferred site for lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
Lumbar puncture:

  • It is done to withdraw cerebrospinal fluid for various diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.
  • The puncture should be done well below the termination of the cord, i.e. lower border of L1.
  • A horizontal line joining the highest points of the iliac crests passes through the spine of the fourth lumbar vertebra. Therefore, the interspinous spaces immediately above and below this landmark can be used with safety.
  • The interspinous space between L3 and L4 is the most preferred site. Because in this region subarachnoid space is more roomy and contains only filum terminale and roots of lumbar, sacral and coccygeal nerves forming the cauda equina.
  • During this procedure, the spine must be fully flexed with patient either lying on the side or seated. So, that the interspinous spaces are opened up to their maximum extent and lower end of spinal cord is slightly raised.
  • The needle is passed inwards and somewhat cranially exactly in the midline.
  • The supraspinous and interspinous ligaments are traversed; and then dura mater is penetrated, the latter with a distinct feel of 'give way'.

Key points: Spinal Cord Levels:

  • Adults: L1-L2
  • Children: L2-L3

questions.text: Which of the following is most preferred site for lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
Conus medullaris syndrome:

  • Due to injury to S2-S4 segments of spinal cord.
  • Features are:
    • Anaesthesia in the perineum. The region is supplied by these three segments.
    • Involvement of bladder and bowel is early as S2-S4 segments carry sacral component of the parasympathetic system which supplies the bladder and lower bowel.
    • Sexual functions are affected as same nerves carry out sexual functions as well.

questions.text: Exteroceptive sensation passes through which of the following tract?
questions.solution:
• The dorsal funiculus consists of two large ascending tracts, the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus, which are also known as the dorsal columns.
  • They are separated by a posterointermediate septum.
  • The dorsal columns contain a high proportion of myelinated fibres carrying to higher levels carrying
    • Proprioceptive (position sense and kinaesthesia) sensation
    • Exteroceptive (touch-pressure) sensation
    • Vibratory sensation
  • These fibres come from several sources: long primary afferent fibres, which enter the cord in the dorsal roots of spinal nerves.
  • It ascend to the dorsal column nuclei in the medulla oblongata.

Key points :

  • Pain (Spino-thalamic tracts)
  • Coordination (Spino-cerebellar tract)
  • Proprioception (Dorsal column tracts)
  • Awareness (Spino-reticular tracts)

choices.text: Contralateral loss of light pain and temperature below the level of the lesion
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature below the level of the lesion
Contralateral loss of light touch and pressure below the level of the lesion
Ipsilateral loss of light touch and pressure below the level of the lesion

questions.text: Damage to anterior spinothalamic tract leads to Loss of:
questions.solution:
• The damage of anterior spinothalamic tract leads to loss of light touch and pressure on the opposite of the body below the level of the lesion.
  • The damage of Lateral spinothalamic tract leads to loss of pain and temperature on the opposite of the body below the level of the lesion.
  • The damage to fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus leads to loss of fine touch and conscious proprioceptive sensations.
  • The damage to anterior and posterior spinocerebellar tracts leads to loss of with unconscious proprioception and muscular coordination.

Key takeaways :

Damage to the anterior spinothalamic tract causes loss of light touch, the lateral spinothalamic tract results in loss of pain and temperature, fasciculus gracilis and cuneatus damage leads to loss of fine touch, and spinocerebellar tract damage results in loss of proprioception and coordination.

questions.text: The fibres of tract of Lissauer give axons to which of the following nuclei?
questions.solution:
The tract of Lissauer:

  • The tract of Lissauer (dorsolateral tract) lies between the apex of the dorsal horn and the surface of the spinal cord, where it surrounds the incoming dorsal root fibres.
  • It is present throughout the spinal cord and is most developed in the upper cervical regions.
  • The tract consists of fine myelinated and unmyelinated axons.
  • Many are the branches of axons in the lateral bundles of the dorsal roots.
  • These axons bifurcate into ascending and descending branches as they enter the cord.
  • The branches travel in the tract of Lissauer for one or two segments and give off collaterals that end on and around neurones in the dorsal horn.
  • The tract also contains propriospinal fibres, some being short axons of small substantia gelatinosa neurones, which re-enter the dorsal horn.

Key takeaways : The tract of Lissauer, located between the dorsal horn and spinal cord surface, consists of myelinated and unmyelinated axons that bifurcate into ascending and descending branches, synapsing in the dorsal horn.

choices.text: Contralateral loss of conscious proprioceptive sensations

questions.text: 30 years old male met with a road traffic accident. He was taken to hospital and under gone with CT scan of spine. He was diagnosed with Brown-Sequard syndrome at the level of T12 Spine. All of the following symptoms are seen below the level of injury, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Brown-Sequard syndrome:

  • This is caused due to hemisection of the spinal cord.
  • Below the level of lesion:
    • Ipsilateral upper motor neuron paralysis caused by pyramidal tract damage.
    • Ipsilateral loss of conscious proprioceptive sensations caused due to damage to posterio white column.
    • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature and touch caused due to damage to lateral spinothalamic and anterior spinothalamic tracts.
  • At the level of lesion:
    • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron paralysis caused due to damage to ventral nerve roots.
    • Ipsilateral anaesthesia over the skin of the segment due to injury to the ventral nerve roots.
  • Above the level: Ipsilateral hyperaesthesia above the level of lesion due to irritation of dorsal nerve roots.

Key takeaways : Hemisection of the spinal cord causes ipsilateral upper motor neuron paralysis and loss of proprioception below the lesion, contralateral loss of pain and temperature, ipsilateral lower motor neuron paralysis and anesthesia at the lesion level, and ipsilateral hyperesthesia above the lesion.

choices.text: Bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensations below the lesion
Bilateral loss of touch and pressure sensations below the lesion
Bilateral loss of conscious proprioceptive sensations
Bilateral loss of vibratory and joint position sensation

questions.text: Which of the following is true about syringomyelia?
questions.solution:
Syringomyelia

  • In this condition, a fluid cavity (or cavities) develops near the center of the spinal cord usually in the cervical segments.
  • This leads to the destruction of the cord involving central canal and its surrounding area.
  • This lesion involves the decussating spinothalamic fibres in the anterior white commissure so that there is bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensations below the lesion
  • Other sensations below the lesion but other sensations are preserved in the uncrossed tracts of posterior columns. Thus, this condition results in what is called dissociated sensory loss.

Key takeaways :

This condition causes fluid cavities in the cervical spinal cord, leading to bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensations below the lesion while preserving other sensations, resulting in dissociated sensory loss.

questions.text: Identify the marked tract:
questions.solution:
Tracts are shown in figure below.


  • In each half of the spinal cord, the white matter is divided into three parts called white columns or funiculi.
  • Posterior white column, between the posterior median septum and posterior horn.
  • Lateral white column, between the anterior and posterior horns.
  • Anterior white column, between the anterior median fissure and the anterior horn.
  • The anterior white columns are joined together by the white commissure.
  • Each white column is made up of tracts which are either ascending (sensory), descending (motor) or intersegmental (association).

questions.text: Which of the following structure is also known as "Bulb"?
questions.solution:
The medulla oblongata:

  • It is the direct upward continuation of the spinal cord, extending from foramen magnum to the lower border of the pons.
  • It forms the lowest part of the brainstem and lies almost vertically in the anterior part of the posterior cranial fossa between the clivus (superior surface of the basi-occiput) in front and the vallecula of the cerebellum behind.
  • The medulla is shaped like a truncated cone (bulb-like) hence its alternative name 'bulb' (cf. bulbar paralysis).
  • Medulla oblongata measures about 3 cm in length, 2 cm in breadth (at the widest part) and 1.25 cm in thickness.

Key takeaways:

The medulla oblongata, a bulb-like structure extends from the foramen magnum to the lower border of the pons and forms the lowest part of the brainstem.

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk and limbs
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face
Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of palate, pharynx and larynx

questions.text: All of the followings are the symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Lateral medullary syndrome of Wallenberg:

  • Also known as posterior inferior cerebellar artery syndrome.
  • The dorsolateral part of the medulla is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, which is usually the branch of the vertebral artery. This artery also supplies the inferior surface of the cerebellum.
  • Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery therefore, affects a wedge-shaped area on the dorsolateral aspect of medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum and produces following signs and symptoms.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, in the trunk and limbs, due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract.
  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face, due to involvement of the spinal nucleus and tract of trigeminal nerve.
  • Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of palate, pharynx and larynx due to involvement of nucleus ambiguous.
  • Ipsilateral ataxia, due to involvement of inferior cerebellar peduncle and cerebellum.
  • Giddiness, due to involvement of vestibular nuclei.
  • Horner's syndrome, due to involvement of descending sympathetic pathway in the reticular formation of medulla.

Key takeaways: Lateral medullary syndrome causes contralateral loss of pain and temperature in the body, ipsilateral facial sensory loss, ataxia, muscle paralysis, giddiness, and Horner's syndrome due to posterior inferior cerebellar artery thrombosis.

questions.text: Figure is showing the transverse section through the medulla oblongata at the caudal end of the fourth ventricle. Identify the hypoglossal nuclei?
questions.solution: The transverse section through the medulla oblongata at the caudal end of fourth ventricle

questions.text: Loss of sense of vibration and position in case of Dejerine syndrome is due to damage to which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
The Medial medullary/Dejerine syndrome:

  • It occurs due to blockage of anterior spinal artery.
  • Features are:
  • Contralateral hemiplegia due to damage to pyramid of medulla.
  • Loss of sense of vibration and position due to damage to medial lemniscus.
  • Paralysis of muscles of tongue on the same side due to injury to XII cranial nerve.

The medial lemniscus

  • The nucleus gracilis and cuneatus give rise to the internal arcuate fibres.
  • These fibres cross to the opposite side where they form a paramedian band of fibres, called the medial lemniscus.
  • In the lemniscus, the body is represented with the head posteriorly and the feet anteriorly.
  • The internal arcuate fibres arising from the cells of gracile and cuneate nuclei (second order sensory neurons conducting sensations of discriminative touch, position and vibration) course forwards and medially around the central grey matter and decussate with corresponding fibres of opposite side in the median plane (sensory decussation) and then turn upwards to ascend as the medial lemniscus on the opposite side close to the median plane.

Key takeaways :

Anterior spinal artery blockage causes contralateral hemiplegia, loss of position sense, and ipsilateral tongue paralysis; medial lemniscus formed by crossed internal arcuate fibres.

questions.text: All of the followings are forming longitudinal fibres in pons, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
White matter of the pons:

  • It consists of longitudinal and transverse fibres.
  • The longitudinal fibres include:
    • The corticospinal tracts
    • The corticonuclear (pyramidal) tracts
    • The corticopontine fibres ending in the pontine nuclei.
  • The transverse fibres are pontocerebellar fibres beginning from the pontine nuclei and going to the opposite half of the cerebellum, through the middle cerebellar peduncle.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is absent in the upper part of pons?
questions.solution: Structural differences of tegmentum in the lower and upper parts of the pons

questions.text: Which of the following lemniscus is a part of auditory pathway
questions.solution:
• On the ventral part of pons bands of fibres made up (from medial to lateral side)
    • Medial lemniscus
    • Spinal lemniscus
    • Trigeminal lemniscus
    • Lateral lemniscus
  • The trapezoid body or corpus trapezoideum is a transverse band of fibres lying just behind the ventral part of the pons. It consists of fibres that arise in the cochlear nuclei of both sides. It is a part of the auditory pathway.
  • The medial lemniscus forms a transverse band on either side of the midline, just behind the trapezoid body. It is joined by anterior spinothalamic tract.
  • The lateral spinothalamic tract (spinal lemniscus) lies lateral to the medial lemniscus.
  • The trigeminal lemniscus conveys fibres of second sensory neurons from the opposite spinal and sensory nuclei of trigeminal nerve. This fibres travelling to the thalamus.
  • The lateral lemniscus is a part of the auditory pathway. It is formed by fibres arising in nuclei lying in close relation to the trapezoid body (superior olivary nucleus and nucleus of trapezoid body).

Key points: The mnemonic "EECOLIMA" for the auditory pathway stands for:

  • E: Ear (Cochlea)
  • E: Eighth cranial nerve (Vestibulocochlear nerve)
  • C: Cochlear nucleus
  • O: Olivary complex (Superior Olivary Nucleus)
  • L: Lateral lemniscus
  • I: Inferior colliculus
  • M: Medial geniculate body
  • A: Auditory cortex (Temporal lobe)

choices.text: Superior colliculus - Lateral geniculate body - Optic tract
Superior colliculus - Medial geniculate body - Optic tract
Superior colliculus - Lateral geniculate body - Auditory tract
Superior colliculus - Medial geniculate body - Auditory tract

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct sequence?
questions.solution:
Superior and inferior colliculi:

  • The dorsal surface of the midbrain presents four rounded elevations:
    • Two superior and two inferior colliculi (or corpora quadrigemina).
    • The colliculi are separated from each other by a cruciform sulcus
  • Thick ridges of white matter extending from lateral side of each colliculus constitute their brachia.
  • The superior and inferior colliculi are concerned with reflex activities triggered by auditory and visual impulses respectively.
  • The superior brachium connect the superior colliculus to the lateral geniculate body and the optic tract, and is made up of optic tract fibres.
  • The inferior brachium connect the inferior colliculus to the medial geniculate body, and is made up of auditory fibres.

Key takeaways :

Superior colliculus - Lateral geniculate body - Optic tract (involved in the visual pathway)

inferior colliculus - Medial geniculate body - Auditory tract (involved in the auditory pathway)

questions.text: Figure is showing the transverse section of midbrain. The marked structure is involved in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
• The marked structure is substantia nigra in the midbrain.
  • The substantia nigra is a curved (crescent-shaped) pigmented band of grey matter (thicker medially than laterally) situated between tegmentum and crus cerebri.
  • Its concavity is smooth and directed towards the tegmentum.
  • From its convex margin spiky processes project into the substance of the crus cerebri.
  • The substantia nigra is a large motor nucleus that extends throughout the length of midbrain.
  • It is divided into two parts:
    • The dorsal part (pars compacta) containing medium sized cells
    • The ventral part (pars reticularis) containing fewer cells. The pars reticularis is intermingled with the fibres of crus cerebri.
  • The degeneration or destruction of substantia nigra causes deficiency of dopamine in the corpus striatum leading to a clinical condition called Parkinsonism.

choices.text: Right homonymous hemianopia with macular involvement
Left homonymous hemianopia with macular involvement
Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
Left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

questions.text: Which of the following will appear in case of injury at the level of the right optic tract?
questions.solution:
• Figure is showing different level of injuries in optic pathway
    • Field defects associated with lesion of visual pathway.
      1. Blindness of left eye
      2. Bitemporal hemianopia
      3. Left nasal hemianopia
      4. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular involvement
      5. Right homonymous hemianopia
      6. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

questions.text:
Arrange these structures in auditory pathway from cranial to caudal side.
1. Lateral lemniscus
2. Superior olivary nucleus
3. Cochlear nuclei
4. Medial geniculate body
5. Inferior colliculus
questions.solution:
Pathway of Hearing:

  • The first neurons of the pathway are located in the spiral ganglion. They are bipolar. Their peripheral processes innervate the spiral organ of Corti while central processes form the cochlear nerve. This nerve terminates in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei.
  • The second neurons lie in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei. Most of the axons arising in these nuclei cross to the opposite side (in the trapezoid body) and terminate in the superior olivary nucleus. (Many fibres end in the nucleus of trapezoid body or of the lateral lemniscus).
  • The third neurons lie in the superior olivary nucleus. Their axons form the lateral lemniscus and reach the inferior colliculus.
  • The fourth neurons lie in the inferior colliculus. Their axons pass through the inferior brachium to reach the medial geniculate body. (Some fibres of lateral lemniscus reach the medial geniculate body without relay in the inferior colliculus).
  • The fifth neurons lie in the medial geniculate body. Their axons form the auditory radiation, which passes through the sublentiform part of the internal capsule to reach the auditory area in the temporal lobe.

Key points:

The mnemonic "EECOLIMA" for the auditory pathway stands for:

  • E: Ear (Cochlea) caudal
  • E: Eighth cranial nerve (Vestibulocochlear nerve)
  • C: Cochlear nucleus
  • O: Olivary complex (Superior Olivary Nucleus)
  • L: Lateral lemniscus
  • I: Inferior colliculus
  • M: Medial geniculate body
  • A: Auditory cortex (Temporal lobe) cranial

questions.text: Which of the following functional component is not present in glossopharyngeal nerve?
questions.solution:
Glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve.
  • It is the nerve of the third branchial arch.
  • It is motor to the stylopharyngeus.
  • It is secretomotor to the parotid gland.
  • It is gustatory to the posterior one third of the tongue including the circumvallate papillae.
  • It is sensory to the pharynx, the tonsil, soft palate, the posterior one-third of the tongue, carotid body and carotid sinus.

Functional components:

  • Special visceral efferent (SVE) fibres arise in nucleus ambiguous and supply the stylopharyngeus muscle.
  • General visceral efferent (GVE) fibres (preganglionic) arise in inferior salivatory nucleus and travel to the otic ganglion. Postganglionic fibres arising in the ganglion to supply the parotid gland.
  • General visceral afferent (GVA) fibres are peripheral processes of cells in inferior ganglion of the nerve. These carry general sensations from the pharynx, palate, posterior one-third of tongue, tonsil, carotid body and carotid sinus to the ganglion. The central processes convey these sensations to lower part of the nucleus of the solitary tract.
  • Special visceral afferent (SVA) fibres are also peripheral processes of cells in the inferior ganglion. They carry sensations of taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue including circumvallate papillae to the inferior ganglion. The central processes convey these sensations to the upper part of the nucleus of the solitary tract.
  • General somatic afferent (GSA) fibres are the peripheral processes of the cells in the inferior ganglion of the nerve. These carry general sensations from the middle ear, proprioceptive fibres from stylopharyngeus. The central processes carry these sensations to nucleus of spinal tract of trigeminal nerve.

choices.text: Nucleus of spinal tract of trigeminal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following nucleus of the vagus nerve is parasympathetic in nature?
questions.solution:
Vagus nerve:

  • It is the tenth cranial nerve.
  • It is so-called because of its extensive ('vague') course, through the head, the neck, the thorax and the abdomen.
  • The fibres of the cranial root of the accessory nerve are also distributed through it.
  • The vagus nerve bears two ganglia-superior and inferior.
    • The superior ganglion is rounded and lies in the jugular foramen.
    • The inferior ganglion is cylindrical and lies near the base of the skull.

Nuclei

  • Nucleus ambiguos (branchiomotor): Mostly a part of the cranial root of accessory nerve; partly of vagus.
  • Dorsal nucleus of vagus (parasympathetic): It is a mixed nucleus, being both motor (visceromotor and secretomotor) and sensory (viscerosensory). Its fibres form the main bulk of the nerve.
  • Nucleus of tractus solitarius (gustatory): Distributed through internal laryngeal nerve to the taste buds of epiglottis and vallecula.
  • Nucleus of spinal tract of trigeminal nerve.

Key takeaways:

The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) has a widespread course and contains superior and inferior ganglia, with nuclei for branchiomotor, parasympathetic, gustatory, and sensory functions.
